subject: libvirt: consider minimal I/O size when selecting cache type
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-05 13:02:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Consider minimal I/O size when selecting cache type

The "none" cache type is not usable when a file-system
has stricter alignment requirements, for example the
xfs file-system created with 4k sector size,
requires all DIRECT I/O request is aligned to 4k.

qemu assumes direct I/O is doable with 512 byte alignment.

_supports_direct_io method will attempt to write exactly 512 byte,
in-order to ensure the underlying file-system is qemu cache=none
compatible.

Change-Id: I5e1ba4e8afa87519cb0ed1120c213f7c318ccef2
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2013-12-05 14:10:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'libvirt: consider minimal I/O size when selecting cache type

The "none" cache type is not usable when a file-system
has stricter alignment requirements, for example the
xfs file-system created with 4k sector size,
requires all DIRECT I/O request is aligned to 4k.

qemu assumes direct I/O is doable with 512 byte alignment.

_supports_direct_io method will attempt to write exactly 512 byte,
in-order to ensure the underlying file-system is qemu cache=none
compatible.

Change-Id: I5e1ba4e8afa87519cb0ed1120c213f7c318ccef2
', 'number': 2}, {'created': '2013-12-05 22:12:45.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/virt/libvirt/test_libvirt.py', 'nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py'], 'message': 'libvirt: consider minimal I/O size when selecting cache type

The "none" cache type is not usable when a file-system
has stricter alignment and minimal I/O size requirements,
for example the xfs file-system created with 4kiB sector size,
requires all DIRECT I/O operation has to be done with
 integer multiple of 4 kiB count/size.

qemu assumes direct I/O is doable with 512 byte minimal size,
so the  _supports_direct_io method needs to check is
the direct I/O doable with 512 byte size.

Change-Id: I5e1ba4e8afa87519cb0ed1120c213f7c318ccef2
', 'number': 3}]
commit_message:
libvirt: consider minimal I/O size when selecting cache type

The "none" cache type is not usable when a file-system
has stricter alignment and minimal I/O size requirements,
for example the xfs file-system created with 4kiB sector size,
requires all DIRECT I/O operation has to be done with
 integer multiple of 4 kiB count/size.

qemu assumes direct I/O is doable with 512 byte minimal size,
so the  _supports_direct_io method needs to check is
the direct I/O doable with 512 byte size.

Change-Id: I5e1ba4e8afa87519cb0ed1120c213f7c318ccef2

commit_message:
Replace xrange in for loop with range

xrange is not supported in python 3, so replace it with six.moves.range

Closes-Bug: #1259978

Change-Id: I321380693d45f7d48f52da2d0f8e4c137763ab0c

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-06 12:57:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'First commit of Tooz

For now the project is composed of a simple API and
use ZooKeeper as the first backend.

Created files:
    - tooz/api.py: the python public API and the abstract class
to implement for backends.

    - tooz/drivers/zookeeper.py: the ZooKeeper backend using the
Kazoo client.

    - tooz/exceptions.py: additional exception will be defined here.

    - tooz/models.py: read only classes, for now the Member class.

    - tooz/tests/test_api.py: Tooz will provide a unique unit-tests suite
which will be run against all backends (thanks to testscenarios).

Change-Id: I4e4cefb52cf6c39a3f6ba35ab1d4ef34a77b5811
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2013-12-09 11:20:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'First commit of Tooz

use ZooKeeper as the first backend.

Created files:

to implement for backends.

    - tooz/drivers/zookeeper.py: the ZooKeeper backend using the
Kazoo client.

    - tooz/exceptions.py: additional exception will be defined here.

    - tooz/models.py: read only classes, for now the Member class.

    - tooz/tests/test_api.py: Tooz will provide a unique unit-tests suite
which will be run against all backends (thanks to testscenarios).

Change-Id: I4e4cefb52cf6c39a3f6ba35ab1d4ef34a77b5811
', 'number': 2}, {'created': '2013-12-09 14:13:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "First commit of Tooz

For now Tooz is composed of a simple API and use ZooKeeper
as the first backend.

The current API provide the group membership protocol like
'servicegroup' in Nova, we enriched it by adding the notion
of capabilities. The notification mechanism is not yet
available. Please read the associated blueprint for more details:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Oslo/blueprints/service-sync

All new backends must implement api.CoordinationDriver and
validate the unit tests. Tooz will provide a unique unit-tests suite
which will be run against all backends.

commit_message:
First commit of Tooz

For now Tooz is composed of a simple API and use ZooKeeper
as the first backend.

The current API provide the group membership protocol like
'servicegroup' in Nova, we enriched it by adding the notion
of capabilities. The API is currently synchronous, we plan to
design an asynchronous one. The notification mechanism is not yet
available. Please read the associated blueprint for more details:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Oslo/blueprints/service-sync

All new backends must implement api.CoordinationDriver and
validate the unit tests. Tooz will provide a unique unit-tests suite
which will be run against all backends.

Change-Id: I4e4cefb52cf6c39a3f6ba35ab1d4ef34a77b5811

commit_message:
port test_keypairs into nova v3 part1

This changeset only copies the v2 files into the appropriate v3
directories unchanged. This is being tried in order to make
reviewing of the porting easier as gerrit will display only what
is actually changed for v3 rather than entirely new files.

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api-tests

Change-Id: I1f49bb12cb193bfa7db069f392f845838d6f8cc4

commit_message:
Add test_discover module to provide a load_tests hook

This commit adds a load_tests hook that will be used to discover the
set of tempest tests that excludes the unit tests. We can't just
discover from the tempest topdir like we previously did because of
mutually exclusive requirements between the normal tempest tests and
the unit tests. (for example mox and mock should not be required for
a tempest run)

Change-Id: I562f033d78e654675fd77af3bf64c44945127bd7

commit_message:
Add nested resource references to resource group

Originally, there was no way to get references to the
resources inside the resource group. This prevented
things like attaching volumes to instances in the group.
This patch allows both aggregated as well as indexed
access to ref id's of the nested resources.

Closes-Bug: #1259830
Change-Id: Id13eb6edd91bfc34d8bab05f429e761fe89ed799

subject: Allow updating empty created v2 images from v1
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-15 23:16:25.000000000', 'files': ['glance/api/v1/images.py'], 'message': 'Allow updating empty created v2 images from v1

When an image is created empty with v2 its size is None.
This behavior was causing v1 to fail when trying to update the image since
it expects an integer - in this case 0.

Change-Id: I8322d012b2ed15cf3fed769776c20b6489f8e9a0
Closes-bug: #1258160
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Allow updating empty created v2 images from v1

When an image is created empty with v2 its size is None.
This behavior was causing v1 to fail when trying to update the image since
it expects an integer - in this case 0.

Change-Id: I8322d012b2ed15cf3fed769776c20b6489f8e9a0
Closes-bug: #1258160

Collapse the three copies of the bare metal NIC template and use the
same dict declaration style used earlier in the script.

commit_message:
Add ovsbridge option to configure-vm

Adds a --ovsbridge for seed VMs. This will cause the public
interface on the seed to be placed on a ovs bridge as an
alternative to the default libvirt network.

Change-Id: Ia19d25087f9b8b21d9ff9da3a41b7a6131b081d9

While lockutils is a useful module, it registers a few oslo.config
options, which can possibly lead to unpleasant issues
(DuplicateOptError) when we split oslo.db from oslo-incubator into a

commit_message:
Drop dependency on lockutils from oslo db code

While lockutils is a useful module, it registers a few oslo.config
options, which can possibly lead to unpleasant issues
(DuplicateOptError) when we split oslo.db from oslo-incubator into a
separate library and reuse both lockutils and oslo.db in target
projects. Unfortunately, we can't just remove usage of oslo.config
options from locktutils as it can break backward compatibility for
existing deployments.
The general approach of solving DuplicateOptError issues for oslo
libraries is not to depend on oslo.config as much as possible. So it's
actually worth to have a small code duplication here for the sake of
oslo.db as a standalone library in the future.

Change-Id: I7e3c5e1e9f7df0fec01e0d484e709cb2375025f1

commit_message:
Fix the grub2 config location for non Ubuntu/Debian systems

Fedora and openSUSE use /boot/grub2/grub.cfg for the grub2
configuration. The path that was used for Fedora before
(/boot/grub/grub.conf) is only valid for older grub releases.

Change-Id: I1e532c73a373a2c3f92211eff52719c2b635b7e3

commit_message:
Add Host Reservation Admin Manager

API extensions are provided using a RPC dispatcher
We need to explicitly mention plugin:method when calling.
If not, it will stick to core methods for ManagerService.

Implements bp:host-provisioning-api

Change-Id: Ice5a07eef54664651c22b6b1185be38062c7296e

commit_message:
Add element to modify /etc/apt/sources.list in dib

Add apt-sources element for Ubuntu OS to override the default
/etc/apt/sources.list in cloudimg.

Set DIB_APT_SOURCES with a proper sources.list file to replace
the default one.

If you want to use this element in tripleo project, set NODE_DIST or
EXTRA_ELEMENTS / UNDERCLOUD_DIB_EXTRA_ARGS / OVERCLOUD_DIB_EXTRA_ARGS
to make it take effect at build time and run time.

e.g. before running devtest.sh:
export DIB_APT_SOURCES=/etc/apt/sources.list
export NODE_DIST="ubuntu apt-sources"

Change-Id: I9ce0d03b506c2948b96382e4d6e85f0aff906450

commit_message:
add support for nova ssh user@host

the nova ssh command is convenient, but it is lacking some basic
niceties that everyone is used to with ssh, for instance actually
doing user@host to connect to an environment. This adds support
for "nova ssh user@host" to work as one would expect.

The functionality is added to both v1.1 and v3 clients. Tests for
this, and other ssh behavior are added to the v1.1 tree (the v3
test_shell.py has not synced over yet).

commit_message:
Extend vlan_splinters control behaviour

Change vlan_splinters control in openstack.json from checkbox to
radio group with 3 values: 'disabled', 'soft', and 'hard'.
'Soft' version always provides a 'trunk' field as a [0].
'Hard' version puts all vlan numbers from this interface to a 'trunk'
field.

bug 1257604

Change-Id: I9c1bbfc95eb777937bf0a9654d6f3cbc912055b9

subject: Implement periodic execution of benchmark scenarios
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-21 09:13:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Implement periodic execution of benchmark scenarios

Being able to run benchmark scenarios not continuously but periodically,
setting the interval between two consecutive benchmark scenario runs,
is a crucial part of making Rally closer to real-world cloud usage scenarios.

Here we add such a capability by adding a new execution type, namely
"periodic". We also add new scenario config parameter "interval" which
enables the user to set the interval between two consecutive scenario
runs in seconds.

A sample benchmark config for periodical booting/deleting 5 servers with
pauses lasting 2 minutes now would look like this:

"benchmark": {
    "NovaServers.boot_and_delete_server": [
        {"args": {"flavor_id": 1,
                  "image_id": "73257560-c59b-4275-a1ec-ab140e5b9979"},
         "execution": "periodic",
         "config": {"times": 5, "interval": 120,
                    "tenants": 3, "users_per_tenant": 2}}
    ]
}

Blueprint flexible-benchmark-config

Change-Id: I21a0a89f60bd5aaf9b3f419f72cdec7842bc7c38

commit_message:
Implement periodic execution of benchmark scenarios

Being able to run benchmark scenarios not continuously but periodically,
setting the interval between two consecutive benchmark scenario launches,
is a crucial part of making Rally closer to real-world cloud usage scenarios.

Here we add such a capability by adding a new execution type, namely
"periodic". We also add new scenario config parameter "interval" which
enables the user to set the interval between two consecutive scenario
launches in minutes.

A sample benchmark config for periodical booting/deleting 5 servers, one
server every 2 minutes, now would look like this:

"benchmark": {
    "NovaServers.boot_and_delete_server": [
        {"args": {"flavor_id": 1,
                  "image_id": "73257560-c59b-4275-a1ec-ab140e5b9979"},
         "execution": "periodic",
         "config": {"times": 5, "period": 2,
                    "tenants": 3, "users_per_tenant": 2}}
    ]
}

Blueprint flexible-benchmark-config

Change-Id: I21a0a89f60bd5aaf9b3f419f72cdec7842bc7c38

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-18 02:31:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Addressed underlying issues associated with misplaced colon

Upon further investigation, the 'NOVA_DBPASS' reference in the
sentence including the misplaced colon should reside with the database
creation step now located further into this section.  The best
solution probably involves opening another bug to clarify this
section by reordering several steps.  For example, database creation
seems like a prerequisite for configuring the 'connection' key in
nova.conf.  Additionally, at least in the Ubuntu guide, configuring
the keys under [keystone_authtoken] in nova.conf should reside with

commit_message:
Addressed underlying issues associated with misplaced colon

Upon further investigation, the 'NOVA_DBPASS' reference in the
sentence including the misplaced colon should reside with the database
creation step now located further into this section.  The best
solution probably involves opening another bug to clarify this
section by reordering several steps.  For example, database creation
seems like a prerequisite for configuring the 'connection' key in
nova.conf.  Additionally, at least in the Ubuntu guide, configuring
the keys under [keystone_authtoken] in nova.conf should reside with
the step configuring Compute to use the Identity Service.

In the meantime, unless suggested otherwise, I changed the minimal
number of items to remove the misplaced colon and improve clarity
using the existing sequence of steps.

Change-Id: I5b24d55f236b6b4cf675707ebce34180187b788e
Closes-Bug: #1261607

Python 3: use six.moves.zip() rather than itertools.izip()

This ensures compatibility with both Python 2 and Python 3.

', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Remove premature restart of Keystone service during configuration

For simplification purposes, restarting the Keystone service
should wait until after configuring all relevant directives
in keystone.conf.

Change-Id: Id26edc20236953215dd18635fbe143f4bc1bc8da
Closes-Bug: #1258651

commit_message:
Strip '/' from api_url string for PXE driver

Because ironic_api_url PXE option used in hardcoded script for posting
callback data we should use only url string without '/' on the end.
It is necessary for case if Ironic API URL option set like
"http://127.0.0.1:6385/".

Change-Id: Iddd237e8aa90fd17f836cfd2060468f34e0de232

commit_message:
Fix XML to JSON parser

Some response bodies has got a lists as part of values for some
keys, but when XML is being parsed this is not considered.
Because of that tests that work correctly for JSON fail for XML.

Closes-bug: #1259870

Change-Id: Ib9b5c2d695258102bbc932f7babc614b0f847455

The lsb_release -si output might contain spaces. E.g. on openSUSE it is
"openSUSE project".

subject: Set the correct path to os-collect-config
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-18 14:07:35.000000000', 'files': ['elements/os-collect-config/install.d/10-os-collect-config'], 'message': "Set the correct path to os-collect-config

os-collect-config is installed in /usr/bin. This adjusts the systemd
service file accordingly to make it work for openSUSE. On Fedora the
wrong path didn't cause any problems because /bin is just a symlink to
/usr/bin there.

Change-Id: I2f02b12f9667920196084ee0abef1c9f676d413a
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Set the correct path to os-collect-config

os-collect-config is installed in /usr/bin. This adjusts the systemd
service file accordingly to make it work for openSUSE. On Fedora the
wrong path didn't cause any problems because /bin is just a symlink to
/usr/bin there.

Change-Id: I2f02b12f9667920196084ee0abef1c9f676d413a

commit_message:
Use Image IDs to make image based updates work

Currently Heat won't know that the Image ID of the names have changed,
so we have to pass in new image ids to make sure the updates actually
deploy the new image.

We change load-image to just output the Image ID to make this task
simpler.

Change-Id: I13031356c09cdeb3a606fd42da91cb8febc9849d

commit_message:
Use BaseTestCase from oslo Part 1

Replace base class for tests with BaseTestCase from
openstack/common/test.py

In this part only tests which inherit
from old base class directly are changed.

Oslo commit: 5d6d24c4e7d674b3f804e250983e835840b45039

Change-Id: Ia4bae39c00cde0a6accc2f6b4e55fc973d7d0ea1

subject: Run DB API tests on a given DB backend
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 4146, 'name': 'Clark Boylan', 'email': 'cboylan@sapwetik.org', 'username': 'cboylan'}, {'_account_id': 5652, 'name': 'David Ripton', 'email': 'dripton@redhat.com', 'username': 'dripton'}, {'_account_id': 6172, 'name': 'Boris Pavlovic', 'email': 'boris@pavlovic.me', 'username': 'boris-42'}, {'_account_id': 6849, 'name': 'Roman Podoliaka', 'email': 'roman.podoliaka@gmail.com', 'username': 'rpodolyaka'}, {'_account_id': 7069, 'name': 'Joshua Hesketh', 'email': 'josh@nitrotech.org', 'username': 'jhesketh'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-17 09:57:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Run DB API tests on a given DB backend.

To proposed solution:
  - uses testrepository facilities to create a separate test
    environment for each process running a portion of test
    cases, i. e. a separate DB is created for each of test processes,
    so that they can safely be run concurrently without any data races
  - DB transactions are used to ensure that DB remains in a clean state
    after running of a test case: each test case is executed within a
    transaction which is rolled back after the test has ended.
    The 'create DB/apply migrations/run a test case/drop DB' pattern
    we currently use for running tests on SQLite in-memory DB is not an
    option, because it would take enormous amount of time to do this
    for MySQL or PostgreSQL
  - a new tox environment is added for running of DB API tests
    (as these are the only tests we want to run on DB backends other
    than SQLite in-memory DB)

To run DB API tests on a specific DB backend do:
  OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION=mysql://test:test@localhost/test tox -e dbapi

Note: this connection is used to create/drop test databases/users, ensure that
the specified users has appropriate rights. If OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION
env variable is not specified, DB API tests are run on SQLite in-memory DB.

Blueprint: db-api-tests-on-all-backends

Change-Id: Ia1128c4f9d1230935a78a2c2363daacafef0f4db

commit_message:
Run DB API tests on a given DB backend

To proposed solution:
  - uses testrepository facilities to create a separate test
    environment for each process running a portion of test
    cases, i. e. a separate DB is created for each of test processes,
    so that they can safely be run concurrently without any data races
  - DB transactions are used to ensure that DB remains in a clean state
    after running of a test case: each test case is executed within a
    transaction which is rolled back after the test has ended.
    The 'create DB/apply migrations/run a test case/drop DB' pattern
    we currently use for running tests on SQLite in-memory DB is not an
    option, because it would take enormous amount of time to do this
    for MySQL or PostgreSQL
  - a new tox environment is added for running of DB API tests
    (as these are the only tests we want to run on DB backends other
    than SQLite in-memory DB)

To run DB API tests on a specific DB backend do:
  OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION=mysql://test:test@localhost/test tox -e dbapi

Note: this connection is used to create/drop test databases/users, ensure that
the specified users has appropriate rights. If OS_TEST_DBAPI_ADMIN_CONNECTION
env variable is not specified, DB API tests are run on SQLite in-memory DB.

Uses code from oslo-incubator, that hasn't been merged yet:
Ic5d3cfe8764b3c04affe79088473255c17535e54

Blueprint: db-api-tests-on-all-backends

Co-authored-By: Ilya Pekelny <ipekelny@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: Ia1128c4f9d1230935a78a2c2363daacafef0f4db

subject: Scripts to run nailgun using external app server.
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-01 14:44:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Scripts for running WSGI application.

Scripts definition:

  nailgun_rcp - run RPC cunsomer in separate process;
  nailgun_keepalive - run KeepAlive checker in separate process;
  share/nailgun_wsgi - WSGI application.

Notes:
  if uses python 2.7 then shared files is installed inside package.
  nailgun_wsgi_path console script returns path to nailgun_wsgi file

  How to use nailgun_wsgi_path:
    uwsgi -s 127.0.0.1:8001 -wsgi-file $(/opt/nailgun/bin/nailgun_wsgi_path)

  if uses python 2.5 then nailgun_wsgi is installed to
  /opt/nailgun/share/nailgun_wsgi

For run nailgun using uwsgi need change supervisord.conf.

Change-Id: I1f5fe75e49feefedee015f4e750d4ae3e2951f33
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2013-11-05 10:55:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Scripts to run nailgun using external app server.

Scripts description:

  nailgun/bin/nailgun_keepalive
     Run KeepAlive checker in separate process;
     Will be installed to <venv>/bin.

  nailgun/bin/nailgun_rcp
     Run RPC consumer in separate process.
     Will be installed to <venv>/bin.

  nailgun/bin/nailgun_wsgi_path
     Return path for nailgun_wsgi;
     Will be installed to <venv>/bin.

  nailgun/wsgi/nailgun_wsgi
     WSGI application.
     Will be installed to share directory (see notes below).

Notes:

  If you are using Python 2.7 then share files is installed inside package.

  If you are using Python 2.6 then nailgun_wsgi is installed to
  <sys.prefix>/share/nailgun_wsgi.

  nailgun_wsgi_path console script returns path to nailgun_wsgi file.
  For example:
    uwsgi -s 127.0.0.1:8001 -wsgi-file $(/opt/nailgun/bin/nailgun_wsgi_path)

Change-Id: I1f5fe75e49feefedee015f4e750d4ae3e2951f33

     Run RPC consumer in separate process.
     Will be installed to <venv>/bin.

  nailgun/bin/nailgun_wsgi_path
     Return path for nailgun_wsgi;
     Will be installed to <venv>/bin.

  nailgun/wsgi/nailgun_wsgi
     WSGI application.
     Will be installed to share directory (see notes below).

Notes:

  If you are using Python 2.7 then shared files are installed inside package.

  If you are using Python 2.6 then nailgun_wsgi is installed to
  <sys.prefix>/share/nailgun_wsgi.

  nailgun_wsgi_path console script returns path to nailgun_wsgi file.
  For example:
    uwsgi -s 127.0.0.1:8001 --wsgi-file $(/opt/nailgun/bin/nailgun_wsgi_path)

Change-Id: I1f5fe75e49feefedee015f4e750d4ae3e2951f33

commit_message:
Scripts to run nailgun using external app server.

Scripts description:

  nailgun/bin/nailgun_keepalive
     Run KeepAlive checker in separate process;
     Will be installed to <venv>/bin.

  nailgun/bin/nailgun_rcp
     Run RPC consumer in separate process.
     Will be installed to <venv>/bin.

  nailgun/bin/nailgun_wsgi_path
     Return path for nailgun_wsgi;
     Will be installed to <venv>/bin.

  nailgun/wsgi/nailgun_wsgi
     WSGI application.
     Will be installed to share directory (see notes below).

Notes:

  If you are using Python 2.7 then shared files are installed inside package.

  If you are using Python 2.6 then nailgun_wsgi is installed to
  <sys.prefix>/share/nailgun_wsgi.

  nailgun_wsgi_path console script returns path to nailgun_wsgi file.
  For example:
    uwsgi -s 127.0.0.1:8001 --wsgi-file $(/opt/nailgun/bin/nailgun_wsgi_path)

Change-Id: I1f5fe75e49feefedee015f4e750d4ae3e2951f33

commit_message:
Use BaseTestCase from oslo Part 2

Replace base class for tests with BaseTestCase from
openstack/common/test.py

Add new base class for tests which need to set
property protections. Inherit StoreClearingUnitTest,
IsolatedUnitTest and UsingPolicyFileMixinTest
from it.

Oslo commit: 5d6d24c4e7d674b3f804e250983e835840b45039

Change-Id: Ifb463ecffc2d7ead9af7fc390353e5d40967bd44

commit_message:
Use /etc/tempest for Tempest conf file

Other projects use /etc to store conf file. According to
lib/template, /etc should be used to store conf file. This
patch makes Tempest compliant.

Change-Id: I862d004bc4b06adc8e7cc86371a6b9fe6179b562

commit_message:
Add a CLI to disable/enable a flavor

If a flavor is disabled, it is invisible to tenants while show a list of flavors.
But if a flavor is already associated with instances, a tenants can still access it by the flavor_id.

usage: nova flavor-disabled <flavor> <disabled>

Sample request:
REQ: curl -i 770bbdfdd5c2472383641bb33b77725a/flavors/12">http://127.0.0.1:8774/v2/770bbdfdd5c2472383641bb33b77725a/flavors/12
                 -d '{"flavor": {"OS-FLV-DISABLED:disabled": true}}

Sample output from CLI:

cloud@devstack:~$ nova help flavor-disabled
usage: nova flavor-disabled <flavor_id> <disabled>

Change the visibility of a flavor between Enabled and Disabled.

Positional arguments:
  <flavor_id>  flavor id.
  <disabled>   value of disabled (true or false).

cloud@devstack:~$ nova flavor-disabled 12 true
+--------------------------+-------+
| Property                 | Value |
+--------------------------+-------+
| OS-FLV-DISABLED:disabled | True  |
| disk                     | 0     |
| extra_specs              | {}    |
| id                       | 12    |
| name                     | test  |
| ram                      | 1024  |
| vcpus                    | 1     |
+--------------------------+-------+

cloud@devstack:~$ nova flavor-list
+----+-----------+-----------+------+-----------+------+-------+-------------+-----------+----------+
| ID | Name      | Memory_MB | Disk | Ephemeral | Swap | VCPUs | RXTX_Factor | Is_Public | Disabled |
+----+-----------+-----------+------+-----------+------+-------+-------------+-----------+----------+
| 1  | m1.tiny   | 512       | 1    | 0         |      | 1     | 1.0         | True      | False    |
| 12 | test      | 1024      | 0    | 0         |      | 1     | 1.0         | True      | True     |
| 13 | test1     | 1024      | 0    | 0         |      | 1     | 1.0         | True      | False    |
| 2  | m1.small  | 2048      | 20   | 0         |      | 1     | 1.0         | True      | False    |
| 3  | m1.medium | 4096      | 40   | 0         |      | 2     | 1.0         | True      | False    |
| 4  | m1.large  | 8192      | 80   | 0         |      | 4     | 1.0         | True      | False    |
| 42 | m1.nano   | 64        | 0    | 0         |      | 1     | 1.0         | True      | False    |
| 5  | m1.xlarge | 16384     | 160  | 0         |      | 8     | 1.0         | True      | False    |
| 84 | m1.micro  | 128       | 0    | 0         |      | 1     | 1.0         | True      | False    |
+----+-----------+-----------+------+-----------+------+-------+-------------+-----------+----------+

Change-Id: I0f244c4bcc7e56d6181445b5d58785607a8dac03
Closes-Bug: #1259262

commit_message:
Port policy from oslo

Port policy from oslo and update glance/api/policy
Update tests.

Add new base class UsingPolicyFileMixinTest for tests which use
policy file. It helps to add the path to tests/etc/policy.json
as policy_file to CONF.

Add unit tests for Enforcer's methods:
- clear
- set_rules
- load_rules

Oslo commit: 76972e2949634abe9fcc9ad36c103cca94300237

Change-Id: I1132b209dfe09d95ba31a741fbacb3fc499ec2cb

subject: Use SHA256 for hashing tokens
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-11 14:53:11.000000000', 'files': ['keystone/common/cms.py'], 'message': 'Use SHA256 for hashing tokens

By coincidence, the table column sizes are big enough for handling
SHA256 hashes, so the only thing needed seems to be to change
the actual hashing algorithm.

Change-Id: I6949ea0bdcfb9c37a83ec968eff9f21cbb974832
Closes-Bug: #1174499
', 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Use SHA256 for hashing tokens

By coincidence, the table column sizes are big enough for handling
SHA256 hashes, so the only thing needed seems to be to change
the actual hashing algorithm.

Change-Id: I6949ea0bdcfb9c37a83ec968eff9f21cbb974832
Closes-Bug: #1174499

commit_message:
Fix simple db's treatment of image tags

Simple db allows setting image tags when calling image_create and returns image
tags as part of the image entity when calling image_get. This is unlike
sqlalchemy driver and is not the correct behavior. Image tags are not part of
the core image entity because v1 of the api should not return them.

This patch also fixes tests that incorrectly expect this behavior.

prerequisite to blueprint remove-simple-driver

Fixes bug 1247655

Change-Id: Iad06279cf59acc542e3b3fc3b72a6050f5c90bc5

commit_message:
Ignore nbactions.xml

This file is a per-user build customization file created by NetBeans,
which is often created for documentation projects to define the
"clean generate-sources" action for easy access in the UI.

commit_message:
Use oslo.db sessions

Keystone was using its own keystone.common.sql module for
database access. oslo-incubator's db.sqlalchemy module provides
the same or better functionality, so use that instead.

DocImpact
- The options that were in the [sql] section are deprecated and
  replaced by options in the [database] section. There are
  also several new options in this section. If database
  configuration is described for another project that uses
  oslo-incubator's db.sqlalchemy module the docs can be shared.

Part of bp use-common-oslo-db-code

Change-Id: I25b717d9616e9d31316441ae3671d2f86229c2bf

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-16 14:17:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'Avoid meaningless comparison that leads to a TypeError

The "requests" module tries to do this comparison in raise_for_status():

    400 <= self.status_code < 500

with "self.status_code" being "None". In Python2, it's a valid comparison, but
in Python3, it triggers a TypeError. We fix it by giving a value to
"self.status_code".

Change-Id: I9ea9ecfb698546a7f6526464aa528441bb7c1ccd
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2013-12-16 14:25:25.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/tests/utils.py'], 'message': 'Avoid meaningless comparison that leads to a TypeError

The "requests" module tries to do this comparison in raise_for_status():

    400 <= self.status_code < 500

with "self.status_code" being "None". In Python2, it's a valid comparison, but
in Python3, it triggers a TypeError. We fix it by giving a valid default value
to "self.status_code".

Change-Id: I9ea9ecfb698546a7f6526464aa528441bb7c1ccd
', 'number': 2}]
commit_message:
Avoid meaningless comparison that leads to a TypeError

The "requests" module tries to do this comparison in raise_for_status():

    400 <= self.status_code < 500

with "self.status_code" being "None". In Python2, it's a valid comparison, but
in Python3, it triggers a TypeError. We fix it by giving a valid default value
to "self.status_code".

Change-Id: I9ea9ecfb698546a7f6526464aa528441bb7c1ccd

subject: Fix obj versioning w/non-ASCII container name
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-18 18:48:32.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/proxy/controllers/test_base.py', 'swift/proxy/controllers/base.py'], 'message': "Fix obj versioning w/non-ASCII container name

If you create a container with a non-ASCII name, and then make another
container with X-Versions-Location: first-cÃ¸ntÃ¥Ã®ner, *and* you're
serializing stuff in memcache as json (the default), when the proxy
tries to make a versioned object, it will crash.

The fix is to make sure that get_container_info() always returns strs,
not unicodes.

The long-term fix would be to get rid of simplejson entirely, as its
decoder can't make up its mind whether JSON strings should be Python
strs or unicodes, and that makes it really really easy to write bugs
like this.

Change-Id: Ib20ea5fb884484a4246d7a21a9f1e2ffd82eb04f
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Fix obj versioning w/non-ASCII container name

If you create a container with a non-ASCII name, and then make another
container with X-Versions-Location: first-cÃ¸ntÃ¥Ã®ner, *and* you're
serializing stuff in memcache as json (the default), when the proxy
tries to make a versioned object, it will crash.

The fix is to make sure that get_container_info() always returns strs,
not unicodes.

The long-term fix would be to get rid of simplejson entirely, as its
decoder can't make up its mind whether JSON strings should be Python
strs or unicodes, and that makes it really really easy to write bugs
like this.

Change-Id: Ib20ea5fb884484a4246d7a21a9f1e2ffd82eb04f

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-10-22 09:14:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Image device should be reset in mount() and teardown()

When fixing bug#1208387, image device name is returned in function
setup_container. But it's missed to reset in function mount() and
teardown().

commit_message:
LXC: Image device should be reset in mount() and teardown()

When fixing bug#1208387, image device name is returned in function
setup_container. But it's missed to reset in function mount() and
teardown().

This patch is to fix it. We now just return the device name when
mounting disk image during setting up container and remove the
member variable 'device' from Class _DiskImage added in last patch.

Closes-bug: #1243108
Related-bug: #1208387

Change-Id: I2aaed6f3367edce4fb23b78f0e979440954609a8

commit_message:
Rename instance_type to flavor in nova.utils and nova.compute.utils

Renames 'instance_type' to 'flavor' in nova.utils and nova.compute.utils
and related tests. Removes the unused fake_get method in
test_compute_utils.

Note that the nova.notifications payload isn't updated yet to store
flavor instead of instance_type so this patch still uses
payload['instance_type'] when processing the notification in
test_compute_utils.

Note that instance_type_id and the instance_type_* keys in
system_metadata are part of the data model and would require a database
migration to change, so those are not part of this patch.

Part of blueprint flavor-instance-type-dedup

Change-Id: I56815e5c8238f8e4ad4e3a2a599310da2b7f4568

commit_message:
Rename instance_type to flavor in nova.cloudpipe

Renames 'instance_type' to 'flavor' in the nova.cloudpipe module.

The deprecated vpn_instance_type option is removed as part of
change I64548e40f so I leave it untouched here.

Part of blueprint flavor-instance-type-dedup

Change-Id: Id4fd757fabfb81ee81999e7978c924aabd0a712b

commit_message:
Removes log generation parameters from EXTRA_OPTS

Reasons:
- No need of using these parameters.
- Logging could be managed on its own by nova.
- Would help to reduce logfiles generation,
  hence making the maintenance easier.
- All other components are already doing this way.

Changes:
- Removed logdir from EXTRA_OPTS.
- Removed logfile_mode from EXTRA_OPTS.

If needed by user, one can modify the nova.conf to
generate logfiles at their desired location.

Change-Id: I301b8a2fa1522965442efa72e21085389ee662f8
Closes-Bug: #1260648

commit_message:
Fix parse_isotime filter into horizon

    parse_isotime was imported from oslo to horizon and became a filter,
    but it can raise an exception. If it occurs the template in which
    we use the filter will be broken. A fix has been made that allows the
    filter to fail silently and display a configurable default value.
    Some tests are now performed on this filter. According to Django
    defaultfilters nothing is logged when the evaluation fails.

Fixes bug #1253161

Change-Id: If44cde62c37371c5de7b7f81860f368f61b066bc

Closes-bug: #1262154

commit_message:
Retry on deadlock in instance_metadata_update

THe instance_metadata_update() method in the sqlalchemy db API may hit a
DBDeadlock, as shown in the bug report.  Apply the necessary decorator
that will have the method retry in that case.

Change-Id: Ice3f13857ba8f4ee1d1d2dc06cef293e6d17daca
Closes-bug: #1262154

commit_message:
Using contain_class instead of include_class

Per rspec-puppet-1.0.1 warning:

DEPRECATION: include_class is deprecated. Use contain_class instead.
Called from .../vendor/gems/rspec-puppet-1.0.1/lib/rspec-puppet/
matchers/include_class.rb:7

Change-Id: I6b410bc4d294bdc6f4feb65a18b213f88b5184f1

', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2013-12-15 22:14:25.000000000', 'files': ['devstack-vm-gate.sh'], 'message': 'Use Fedora 20 for DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_HEAT_SLOW

This adds a Fedora 20 image name to
$HEAT_FETCHED_TEST_IMAGE so that tempest is configured to
use it for orchestration tests requiring an image.

Fedora 20 has heat-cfntools pre-installed, so there is no

commit_message:
Use Fedora 20 for DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_HEAT_SLOW

This adds a Fedora 20 image name to
$HEAT_FETCHED_TEST_IMAGE so that tempest is configured to
use it for orchestration tests requiring an image.

Fedora 20 has heat-cfntools pre-installed, so there is no
current need to run diskimage-builder during the gate run.

A separate change to devstack/stackrc will add the actual
URL to IMAGE_URLS which corresponds to this image name.

Change-Id: Iddfc6629f7c0108cb2a19c09e719ed839989bdb5

Adds method for misc options

This change adds support for miscellaneous options to be set.
Things that haven't been added as attributes, or specifically,
third party additions that don't belong in stackforge (e.g. cobalt)

commit_message:
Adds method for misc options

This change adds support for miscellaneous options to be set.
Things that haven't been added as attributes, or specifically,
third party additions that don't belong in stackforge (e.g. cobalt)

Change-Id: Ib312333283275fa3581c912f8c55c8f2c6191705

Therefore, make the tests that rely on it dependent on whether

Closes-bug: #1231152

commit_message:
Fix failures when l3_agent_scheduler ext is not available

Some plugins do not support the L3 agent scheduler extension.
Therefore, make the tests that rely on it dependent on whether
this is actually available in the plugin under test.

Change-Id: I3154b646677379a34465c6826b71d4ad72c471a2
Closes-bug: #1231152

commit_message:
Bug #1261894: Deleting Record With BIND 9 Driver Fails

Fix the delete_record() method so it deletes the record in the central storage before the BIND 9 backend gets the request to delete the record.

Change-Id: I0d1e00f441d2f2026734d90e7f015fdd40c7e137
Closes-bug: #1261894

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-03 21:00:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'scenario cross_tenant_connectivity

This test suite assumes that Nova has been configured to boot VM's with
Neutron-managed networking, and attempts to verify cross tenant connectivity
as follows

ssh:
    in order to overcome "ip namespace", each tenant has an "access point"  VM
    with floating-ip open to incoming ssh connection allowing network commands
    (ping/ssh) to be executed from within the tenant-network-namespace
    Tempest host performs key-based authentication to the ssh server via
    floating IP address

setup:
    for each tenant (demo and alt):
        1. create a network&subnet
        2. create a router (if public router isn't configured)
        3. connect tenant network to public network via router
        4. create an access point:
            a. a security group open to incoming ssh connection
            b. a VM with a floating ip
        5. for demo tenant - create another server to test in-tenant connections

connectivity test is done by pinging destination server via source server ssh
connection.
success - ping returns
failure - ping_timeout reached

tests:
        1. _verify_network_details
        2. _verify_mac_addr: for each access point verify that
        (subnet, fix_ip, mac address) are as defined in the port list
        3. _test_in_tenant_block: test that in-tenant traffic is disabled
        without rules allowing it
        4. _test_in_tenant_allow: test that in-tenant traffic is enabled once an
        appropriate rule has been created
        5. _test_cross_tenant_block: test that cross-tenant traffic is disabled
        without a rule allowing it on destination tenant
        6. _test_cross_tenant_allow:
            * test that cross-tenant traffic is enabled once an
            * appropriate rule
            has been created on destination tenant.
            * test that reverse traffic is still blocked
            * test than revesre traffic is enabled once an
            * appropriate
            * rule has been created on source tenant

assumptions:
        1. alt_tenant/user existed and is different from demo_tenant/user
        2. Public network is defined and reachable from the Tempest host
        3. Public router can either be:
            * defined, in which case all tenants networks can
            * connect directly
            to it, and cross tenant check will be done on the private IP of the
            destination tenant
            or
            * not defined (empty string), in which case each tanant
            * will have
            its own router connected to the public network

    resources

compute_client with tenant credentials

set_compute_context(tenant) - sets self.compute_client to a
tenant-relevant compute_client

remote_client:
    1. ping_host - ping host via ssh client
    2. get_mac_address - retrieve ssh server mac

manager:
    1. move network and router creation to mananger
    (from scenario/test_network_basic_ops)
    2. add set_resource=True to _create_secgroup_rule() so you can
create a rule
    not deleted by tearDown this is workaround for bug 1247568 in
    python-neutronclient (preventing tearDownClass from ignoring deleted
neutron
    resources

commit_message:
scenario cross_tenant_connectivity

test conectivity between VMs in the same tenant and on different
tenants.
for each case, test that default state blocks traffic(*), that security
rules allow only specified traffic

(*)negative connectivity check is skipped until bug 1252620 is fixed
   TODO(yfried): enable them once bug is fixed

Also adds workaround for bug 1247568 in python-neutronclient (preventing
tearDownClass from ignoring deleted neutron resources

Change-Id: I212873d46e20ff3161e376105af18020b1cf1c9d

subject: Refactor network client
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-15 13:58:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Refactor network client

This patch implements the following steps in network client refactoring
1) Automatically 'generated' list_, show_, delete_ methods for most of
the resources
2) XML and JSon client implementations inherit common base
3) Every list method now supports filters

This change allow to remove existing list_, show_ and delete_ methods for
simple resources from both clients.

Some tests were fixed to simplify mapping between client method name and
resulting URI (example: list_floatingips instead of list_floating_ips)

Change-Id: I0eb46f8e3d90809dbfc54d4a250cd6aecfdc2c3b

commit_message:
Refactor network client

This patch implements the following steps in network client refactoring
1) Automatically 'generated' list_, show_, delete_ methods for most of
the resources
2) XML and JSon client implementations inherit common base
3) Every list method now supports filters

This change allow to remove existing list_, show_ and delete_ methods for
simple resources from both clients.

Some tests were fixed to simplify mapping between client method name and
resulting URI (example: list_floatingips instead of list_floating_ips)

Change-Id: I0eb46f8e3d90809dbfc54d4a250cd6aecfdc2c3b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-27 16:48:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'This patch adds a user authentication of incoming request.
 Currently two authentication strategies are supported:
 noauth (no authentication) and keystone.

This patch also includes unit test for authentication control via
configuration parameter auth_strategy. It adds
solum.openstack.common.fixtures component in order to use
openstack.config fixture in unit tests.

This patch adds python_keystoneclient into requirements.txt

Change-Id: I16aa0ba66eb8f5bf74e955245baba43118c89057
Implements: blueprint user-authentication
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2013-11-28 18:22:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'This patch adds a user authentication of incoming request.

A new option enable_authentication is introduced in solum.conf
to control incoming request authentication via keystone. By default this
option has value False.
If this option is enabled (has value True) a keystoneclient.auth_token
middleware will be installed.

This patch adds python_keystoneclient into requirements.txt

Change-Id: I16aa0ba66eb8f5bf74e955245baba43118c89057
Implements: blueprint user-authentication
', 'number': 2}, {'created': '2013-12-10 00:49:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'This patch adds a user authentication of incoming request.

A new option enable_authentication is introduced in solum.conf
to control incoming request authentication via keystone. By default this
option has value True.
If this option is enabled (has value True) a keystoneclient.auth_token
middleware will be installed.

This patch adds python_keystoneclient into requirements.txt
Change-Id: I16aa0ba66eb8f5bf74e955245baba43118c89057
Implements: blueprint user-authentication
', 'number': 3}, {'created': '2013-12-10 01:47:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'This patch adds a user authentication of incoming request.

A new option enable_authentication is introduced in solum.conf
to control incoming request authentication via keystone. By default this
option has value True.
If this option is enabled (has value True) a keystoneclient.auth_token

commit_message:
This patch adds a user authentication of incoming request.

A new option enable_authentication is introduced in solum.conf
to control incoming request authentication via keystone. By default this
option has value True.
If this option is enabled (has value True) a keystoneclient.auth_token
middleware will be installed.

test_functional.py file has beed removed as it is not
compatible with authentication changes. Tests from test_functional file
will be added to functionaltest folder by a separate commit.

This patch adds python_keystoneclient into requirements.txt
Change-Id: I16aa0ba66eb8f5bf74e955245baba43118c89057
Implements: blueprint user-authentication

commit_message:
Parameterize the dhcp_lease_time

This change allows the site operator to override the
default dhcp_lease_time provided to DHCP clients in the
event they want a different value from the 120s default.

Change-Id: I7020120ef3ffcf5d9e73f48f3ebdaff853298842

commit_message:
Make wsgi attributes overridable

Allow the site operator to override wsgi attributes
and allows access to an api_workers attribute present
in Havana but also in Grizzly sites that are patched with
the following patch:

https://gist.github.com/alanmeadows/7770570

Change-Id: I6495c9f6095e686d9504ad8dde59c9b9696dc3ba

commit_message:
Make Heat's non_empty_stack usable without a server

We don't really need to test with a server to check Heat's
API responses. So just use a trivial resource type (a LaunchConfig)
to create some objects that we can query against. Now we can use
this test to gate.

Change-Id: I71bc065d8a1d2064ca90406543a376ce4d477275

subject: ceph::mon create or destroy monitors
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1918, 'name': 'FranÃ§ois Charlier', 'email': 'francois.charlier@redhat.com', 'username': 'francois-charlier'}, {'_account_id': 2064, 'name': 'Loic Dachary', 'email': 'loic@dachary.org', 'username': 'dachary'}, {'_account_id': 2481, 'name': 'Rongze Zhu', 'email': 'zrzhit@gmail.com', 'username': 'zrzhit'}, {'_account_id': 7156, 'name': 'Mathieu GagnÃ©', 'email': 'mgagne@calavera.ca', 'username': 'mgagne'}, {'_account_id': 8797, 'name': 'Andrew Woodward', 'email': 'xarses@gmail.com', 'username': 'xarses'}, {'_account_id': 9061, 'name': 'David Moreau Simard', 'email': 'moi@dmsimard.com', 'username': 'dmsimard'}, {'_account_id': 9064, 'name': 'Danny Al-Gaaf', 'email': 'danny.al-gaaf@bisect.de', 'username': 'dalgaaf'}, {'_account_id': 9133, 'name': 'Puppet Ceph CI', 'username': 'puppetceph', 'inactive': True, 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-17 22:06:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'implement mon::ceph

This is a draft implementation that can deploy a single mon + destroy
it. It successfully runs in the integration test environment.

It raises a few questions and is open for discussion:

* exposing configuration thru facts

  It is essenstial for the puppet module to know the values of ceph
  configuration options. The mon-data configuration value is where files
  such as done or upstart must be created. It would also be quite
  difficult ( and time consuming to maintain) to implement the puppet
  module so that it exactly and precisely reflect how ceph sets all
  configuration options.

  By exposing the configuration via custom facts, the puppet module can
  fully delegate the interpretation of configuration options to ceph and
  be 100% sure they are accurate. In a nutshell, this is done by
  creating a facter script that runs

      ceph --id ID --show-config

  The downside of this approach is that the puppet module must be run
  twice : first to install the facter script, second to do the actual
  work based on the values exposed by the facter script. For instance,
  the ceph::mon module does

      install ceph --id ID --show-config in /etc/facter/facts.d/ceph.sh

      if $::mon_data != undef {
          deploy mon
      }

   the first time around, the script is installed and the $::mon_data
   fact is null, therefore nothing else is done. The second time around,
   the script is in place and $::mon_data == /var/lib/ceph/mon/mon-a and
   the "deploy mon" part of the puppet module is run.

* resource ordering

  The resource ordering uses a form like:

     class { ...
     }
     ->
     class { ...
     }

   when possible so that is looks like sequential code although it is
   not. When conditional statements must be included ( such as dealing
   with various key managemnt policies ), the following for is used to
   relate to the previous resource:

     File['foobar'] -> Class['frobnitz']

* coping with key management policies

   All key management are enumerated with the following cases:

   * no key management ( auth_supported = 'none' )
     the keyring file is set to /dev/null when --mkfs because there is
     no way to do otherwise and the keyring file is created empty
     in the mon-data directory because it is checked at boot time
     although it is not used

   * keys provided in the puppet master
     the puppetmaster contains hardcoded ( manually generated ) keys
     that are passed as arguments to the ceph::mon class as follows:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        key = 'xxxxxxxxxxxxx',
     }

     the key is set in a temporary keyfile that is removed after the
     --mkfs of the monitor.

   * keys managed by the puppet-secret module or a similar class
     the key are also controlled by the puppetmaster which is ultimately
     trusted, but they are not set in clear. Instead they are exposed
     as follows:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        key = secret('mon-key'),
     }

     from the point of view of the ceph::mon module, they are no
     different than the hardcoded keys.

   * keys managed by a mechanism external to puppet
     the puppetmaster does not have permission to retrieve the keys. It
     relies on a third party copy mechanism to prepare the keyring
     before ceph::mon is called. The ceph::mon module assumes that the
     keyring file already exists when it is called and that it is placed
     exactly where it should be. For instance:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        keyring = '/tmp/ceph-mon-a.kering',
     }

     more information about this use case at
     https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Puppet-openstack/ceph-blueprint#Keeping_keys_.2F_secrets_out_of_Puppet

   The ceph::mon module implements all cases by requiring that either
   the $key or $keyring arguments are provided when $authentication_type
   == cephx and that they are mutually exclusive.

* articulation with the configuration file

  ceph::mon requires that class { 'ceph': ... } is called before it to
  set the configuration file. It heavily relies on it to properly setup
  the monitor.

  in order to support the deployment of multiple ceph clusters on the
  same host, the ceph.conf configuration file can be passed as an
  argument to ceph::mon.

Change-Id: Ic56a4124738006f7946ee9c166295f7048cb7854
Signed-off-by: Loic Dachary <loic@dachary.org>
', 'number': 1}, {'created': '2013-11-17 22:18:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': 'draft implementation of mon::ceph

This is a draft implementation that can deploy a single mon + destroy
it. It successfully runs in the integration test environment.

It raises a few questions and is open for discussion:

* exposing configuration thru facts

  It is essenstial for the puppet module to know the values of ceph
  configuration options. The mon-data configuration value is where files
  such as done or upstart must be created. It would also be quite
  difficult ( and time consuming to maintain) to implement the puppet
  module so that it exactly and precisely reflect how ceph sets all
  configuration options.

  By exposing the configuration via custom facts, the puppet module can
  fully delegate the interpretation of configuration options to ceph and
  be 100% sure they are accurate. In a nutshell, this is done by
  creating a facter script that runs

      ceph --id ID --show-config

  The downside of this approach is that the puppet module must be run
  twice : first to install the facter script, second to do the actual
  work based on the values exposed by the facter script. For instance,
  the ceph::mon module does

      install ceph --id ID --show-config in /etc/facter/facts.d/ceph.sh

      if $::mon_data != undef {
          deploy mon
      }

   the first time around, the script is installed and the $::mon_data
   fact is null, therefore nothing else is done. The second time around,
   the script is in place and $::mon_data == /var/lib/ceph/mon/mon-a and
   the "deploy mon" part of the puppet module is run.

* resource ordering

  The resource ordering uses a form like:

     class { ...
     }
     ->
     class { ...
     }

   when possible so that is looks like sequential code although it is
   not. When conditional statements must be included ( such as dealing
   with various key managemnt policies ), the following for is used to
   relate to the previous resource:

     File['foobar'] -> Class['frobnitz']

* coping with key management policies

   All key management are enumerated with the following cases:

   * no key management ( auth_supported = 'none' )
     the keyring file is set to /dev/null when --mkfs because there is
     no way to do otherwise and the keyring file is created empty
     in the mon-data directory because it is checked at boot time
     although it is not used

   * keys provided in the puppet master
     the puppetmaster contains hardcoded ( manually generated ) keys
     that are passed as arguments to the ceph::mon class as follows:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        key = 'xxxxxxxxxxxxx',
     }

     the key is set in a temporary keyfile that is removed after the
     --mkfs of the monitor.

   * keys managed by the puppet-secret module or a similar class
     the key are also controlled by the puppetmaster which is ultimately
     trusted, but they are not set in clear. Instead they are exposed
     as follows:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        key = secret('mon-key'),
     }

     from the point of view of the ceph::mon module, they are no
     different than the hardcoded keys.

   * keys managed by a mechanism external to puppet
     the puppetmaster does not have permission to retrieve the keys. It
     relies on a third party copy mechanism to prepare the keyring
     before ceph::mon is called. The ceph::mon module assumes that the
     keyring file already exists when it is called and that it is placed
     exactly where it should be. For instance:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        keyring = '/tmp/ceph-mon-a.kering',
     }

     more information about this use case at
     https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Puppet-openstack/ceph-blueprint#Keeping_keys_.2F_secrets_out_of_Puppet

   The ceph::mon module implements all cases by requiring that either
   the $key or $keyring arguments are provided when $authentication_type
   == cephx and that they are mutually exclusive.

* articulation with the configuration file

  ceph::mon requires that class { 'ceph': ... } is called before it to
  set the configuration file. It heavily relies on it to properly setup
  the monitor.

  in order to support the deployment of multiple ceph clusters on the
  same host, the ceph.conf configuration file can be passed as an
  argument to ceph::mon.

Change-Id: Ic56a4124738006f7946ee9c166295f7048cb7854
Signed-off-by: Loic Dachary <loic@dachary.org>

', 'number': 4}, {'created': '2013-11-28 00:21:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "ceph::mon create or destroy monitors

* Minimize redundant hard coded configuration values

  cluster is undef and turned into --cluster $cluster only if specified

  mon-data is not specified, instead it is obtained reliably from
  ceph-conf on the local machine. The alternative would be to specify
  mon-data as an argument but that would be error prone because it would
  have to be duplicated in ceph::conf. It would also be a risk for
  errors that are difficult to diagnose because of hierarchical
  evaluation rules:

    [global]
    mon_data = /frob

  ceph::mon { 'foo': mon_data => '/frob' } => good

    [mon.foo]
    mon_data = /foo/bar

  ceph::mon { 'foo': mon_data => '/frob' } => now it is bad

* resource ordering

  The resource ordering uses a form like:

     class { ...
     }
     ->
     class { ...
     }

   when possible so that is looks like sequential code. When conditional
   statements must be included ( such as dealing with various key
   managemnt policies ), the following for is used to relate to the
   previous resource:

     File['foobar'] -> Class['frobnitz']

* coping with key management policies

   All key management are enumerated with the following cases:

   * no key management ( auth_supported = 'none' )

     the keyring file is set to /dev/null when --mkfs because there is
     no way to do otherwise and the keyring file is created empty
     in the mon-data directory because it is checked at boot time
     although it is not used

   * keys provided in the puppet master

     the puppetmaster contains hardcoded ( manually generated ) keys
     that are passed as arguments to the ceph::mon class as follows:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        key = 'xxxxxxxxxxxxx',
     }

     the key is set in a temporary keyfile that is removed after the
     --mkfs of the monitor.

   * keys managed by the puppet-secret module or a similar class

     the key are also controlled by the puppetmaster which is ultimately
     trusted, but they are not set in clear. Instead they are exposed
     as follows:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        key = secret('mon-key'),
     }

     from the point of view of the ceph::mon module, they are no
     different than the hardcoded keys.

   * keys managed by a mechanism external to puppet

     the puppetmaster does not have permission to retrieve the keys. It
     relies on a third party copy mechanism to prepare the keyring
     before ceph::mon is called. The ceph::mon module assumes that the
     keyring file already exists when it is called and that it is placed
     exactly where it should be. For instance:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        keyring = '/tmp/ceph-mon-a.kering',
     }

     more information about this use case at
     https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Puppet-openstack/ceph-blueprint#Keeping_keys_.2F_secrets_out_of_Puppet

   The ceph::mon module implements all cases by requiring that either
   the $key or $keyring arguments are provided when $authentication_type
   is cephx and that they are mutually exclusive.

* articulation with the configuration file

  ceph::mon requires that class { 'ceph': ... } is called before it to
  set the configuration file. It heavily relies on it to properly setup
  the monitor.

  in order to support the deployment of multiple ceph clusters on the
  same host, the cluster name can be passed as an argument to ceph::mon
  and implies loading /etc/ceph/${cluster}.conf when passed to ceph-mon

Change-Id: Ic56a4124738006f7946ee9c166295f7048cb7854
Signed-off-by: Loic Dachary <loic@dachary.org>

   the $key or $keyring arguments are provided when $authentication_type
   is cephx and that they are mutually exclusive.

* articulation with the configuration file

  ceph::mon requires that class { 'ceph': ... } is called before it to
  set the configuration file. It heavily relies on it to properly setup
  the monitor.

  in order to support the deployment of multiple ceph clusters on the
  same host, the cluster name can be passed as an argument to ceph::mon
  and implies loading /etc/ceph/${cluster}.conf when passed to ceph-mon

Closes-Bug: #1251443

Change-Id: Ic56a4124738006f7946ee9c166295f7048cb7854
Signed-off-by: Loic Dachary <loic@dachary.org>
", 'number': 8}, {'created': '2013-11-28 12:22:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "ceph::mon create or destroy monitors

ceph-blueprint#mon

* Minimize redundant hard coded configuration values

  cluster is undef and turned into --cluster $cluster only if specified

  mon-data is not specified, instead it is obtained reliably from
  ceph-conf on the local machine. The alternative would be to specify
  mon-data as an argument but that would be error prone because it would
  have to be duplicated in ceph::conf. It would also be a risk for
  errors that are difficult to diagnose because of hierarchical
  evaluation rules:

    [global]
    mon_data = /frob

  ceph::mon { 'foo': mon_data => '/frob' } => good

    [mon.foo]
    mon_data = /foo/bar

  ceph::mon { 'foo': mon_data => '/frob' } => now it is bad

* resource ordering

  The resource ordering uses a form like:

     class { ...
     }
     ->
     class { ...
     }

   when possible so that is looks like sequential code. When conditional
   statements must be included ( such as dealing with various key
   managemnt policies ), the following for is used to relate to the
   previous resource:

     File['foobar'] -> Class['frobnitz']

* coping with key management policies

   All key management are enumerated with the following cases:

   * no key management ( auth_supported = 'none' )

     the keyring file is set to /dev/null when --mkfs because there is
     no way to do otherwise and the keyring file is created empty
     in the mon-data directory because it is checked at boot time
     although it is not used

   * keys provided in the puppet master

     the puppetmaster contains hardcoded ( manually generated ) keys
     that are passed as arguments to the ceph::mon class as follows:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        key = 'xxxxxxxxxxxxx',
     }

     the key is set in a temporary keyfile that is removed after the
     --mkfs of the monitor.

   * keys managed by the puppet-secret module or a similar class

     the key are also controlled by the puppetmaster which is ultimately
     trusted, but they are not set in clear. Instead they are exposed
     as follows:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        key = secret('mon-key'),
     }

     from the point of view of the ceph::mon module, they are no
     different than the hardcoded keys.

   * keys managed by a mechanism external to puppet

     the puppetmaster does not have permission to retrieve the keys. It
     relies on a third party copy mechanism to prepare the keyring
     before ceph::mon is called. The ceph::mon module assumes that the
     keyring file already exists when it is called and that it is placed
     exactly where it should be. For instance:

     class { 'ceph::mon':
        keyring = '/tmp/ceph-mon-a.kering',
     }

     more information about this use case in the bp.

   The ceph::mon module implements all cases by requiring that either
   the $key or $keyring arguments are provided when $authentication_type
   is cephx and that they are mutually exclusive.

* articulation with the configuration file

  ceph::mon requires that class { 'ceph': ... } is called before it to
  set the configuration file. It heavily relies on it to properly setup
  the monitor.

  in order to support the deployment of multiple ceph clusters on the
  same host, the cluster name can be passed as an argument to ceph::mon
  and implies loading /etc/ceph/${cluster}.conf when passed to ceph-mon

Closes-Bug: #1251443

Change-Id: Ic56a4124738006f7946ee9c166295f7048cb7854
Signed-off-by: Loic Dachary <loic@dachary.org>

commit_message:
ceph::mon create or destroy monitors

* ceph::mon resource

  create a MON if ensure == present or destroy one if absent

  all combinations of keys / keyring as specified in the blueprint are
  supported

* integration tests cover all cases and unit tests are implemented to
  ensure syntax correctness

* minor corrections to other classes are included ( two nodes for
  integration tests, default values for the ceph class etc. )

* A ceph::mons class wrapper is created for compatibility with
  scenario_node_terminus

Closes-Bug: #1251443

Change-Id: Ic56a4124738006f7946ee9c166295f7048cb7854
Signed-off-by: Loic Dachary <loic@dachary.org>

commit_message:
remove duplicate six import

apparently we had a duplicate import of six, noticed by pyflakes
in my buffer when loading up the file.

Change-Id: I2f5e03d1862711c7214c1e33b4500693aaabf567

subject: SSH connection related cleanups
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-11-20 09:31:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Fix false negative ssh connection check

Tempest usually start the ssh connection attempts before the
sshd is fully configured. If tempest does do an authentication attempt when the
cloud image reconfiguring the sshd or setting up the public key, we
can see not handled SSHException within the timeout period.
The not handled SSHException leads to false negative connection check.

This change extending the set of the not fatal exceptions during
connection wait to SSHException which includes the already accepted
 AuthenticationException family.

The RemoteClient.can_authenticate become obsolete, when the
test_connection_auth become the part of it's __init__ method.
Removing all usage of the can_authenticate and the method itself.

test_connection_auth method changed to exception raiser method, in order
to avid the unwanted catch-and-raise-new-exception code from the
RemoteClient.

Removing test_can_log_into_created_server because it does not test
anything new, all test cases which uses ssh does the same job.

Use similar ssh connectivity check with the test_network_basic_ops,
as with all other test cases, so using the implicit
connection validation of the RemoteClient.

Change-Id: Ia2599f7f2c2fdc6fcbf7ad3337d82adcc50e4d16
", 'number': 1}, {'created': '2013-11-20 16:34:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Fix false negative ssh connection check

Tempest usually start the ssh connection attempts before the
sshd is fully configured. If tempest does do an authentication attempt when the
cloud image reconfiguring the sshd or setting up the public key, we
can see not handled SSHException within the timeout period.
The not handled SSHException leads to false negative connection check.

This change extending the set of the not fatal exceptions during
connection wait to SSHException which includes the already accepted
 AuthenticationException family.

The RemoteClient.can_authenticate become obsolete, when the
test_connection_auth become the part of it's __init__ method.
Removing all usage of the can_authenticate and the method itself.

test_connection_auth method changed to exception raiser method, in order
to avid the unwanted catch-and-raise-new-exception code from the
RemoteClient.

Removing test_can_log_into_created_server because it does not test
anything new, all test cases which uses ssh does the same job.

Use similar ssh connectivity check with the test_network_basic_ops,
as with all other test cases, so using the implicit
connection validation of the RemoteClient.

Change-Id: Ia2599f7f2c2fdc6fcbf7ad3337d82adcc50e4d16
", 'number': 2}, {'created': '2013-11-20 16:45:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'message': "Fix false negative ssh connection check

Tempest usually start the ssh connection attempts before the
sshd is fully configured. If tempest does do an authentication attempt when the
cloud image reconfiguring the sshd or setting up the public key, we
can see not handled SSHException within the timeout period.
The not handled SSHException leads to false negative connection check.

This change extending the set of the not fatal exceptions during
connection wait to SSHException which includes the already accepted
 AuthenticationException family.

The RemoteClient.can_authenticate become obsolete, when the
test_connection_auth become the part of it's __init__ method.
Removing all usage of the can_authenticate and the method itself.

test_connection_auth method changed to exception raiser method, in order
to avid the unwanted catch-and-raise-new-exception code from the
RemoteClient.

Removing test_can_log_into_created_server because it does not test
anything new, all test cases which uses ssh does the same job.

Use similar ssh connectivity check with the test_network_basic_ops,
as with all other test cases, so using the implicit
connection validation of the RemoteClient.

Change-Id: Ia2599f7f2c2fdc6fcbf7ad3337d82adcc50e4d16

commit_message:
SSH connection related cleanups

Catching only the SSHException the AuthenticationException is
 a subclass of the SSHException in the ssh.py.

test_connection_auth method changed to exception raiser method, in order
to avid unwanted catch-and-raise-new-exception code from the
RemoteClient.

Use similar ssh connectivity check with the test_network_basic_ops,
as with all other test cases, so using the implicit
connection validation of the RemoteClient.

Improve ssh connection logging by logging the reason of the connection
failure.

Change-Id: Ia2599f7f2c2fdc6fcbf7ad3337d82adcc50e4d16

commit_message:
Remove roles from OS-TRUST list responses

According to the docs, the list responses should not contain
the roles, only the detailed response when you get a trust
explicitly by ID.  So remove the roles and modify the tests
appropriately.

Note it was also observed that expires_at is present in all
GET resonses, but not in the docs, but this has been agreed
as a docs error so will be addressed via a docs patch.

Change-Id: I5387021a53f3284add9e5e71e9e005c4dd31b76c
Closes-Bug: #1245590

Due to bug #1239303 the wrong user could be used when obtaining a
trust-scoped v2 token, so add a sanity check to ensure we can rely on
the user_id, using the trustor_user_id (which we currently store but

Due to bug #1239303 the wrong user could be used when obtaining a

commit_message:
Add sanity check to ensure user_id can be trusted

Due to bug #1239303 the wrong user could be used when obtaining a
trust-scoped v2 token, so add a sanity check to ensure we can rely on
the user_id, using the trustor_user_id (which we currently store but
don't use) to ensure impersonation is working as expected.

Change-Id: I0481a4d96c514d0d61676d27f615c735e89ad03e

commit_message:
Correct create_trust_context docstring

The docstring in heat_keystoneclient create_trust_context incorrectly
references a test on deferred_auth_method which ended up happening in
parser.Stack, so correct it to accurately reflect the code.

Change-Id: I0d763b44a57e9b9e641e36c418445441702db07e

commit_message:
Add support for NSX/NVP Metadata services

This is a feature patch (2 of 3) that adds support for
Metadata services provided by the NSX (aka NVP) platform.

It also implements the handling of port events so that
dhcp and metadata configuration in NSX/NVP is updated
if port attributes such as fixed_ips and device_id are
updated.

Partial-implements blueprint nsx-integrated-services

Change-Id: Id2b9125b49c0e15e717605ec6ba3dea5d32ee755

commit_message:
Remove deprecated config aliases

Now that we are in Icehouse, remove deprecated config options from
Havana.

I57b5861e57168c44729934757e732de962f3d91a incorrectly labeled the vmware
options as deprecated in icehouse when they were actually deprecated in havana in
Ic9b425a3d9ea2b614643ba8d3db50b065947c806

DocImpact: Configurations that were previously deprecated in Icehouse
are now not recognized.

Change-Id: I64548e40f6cea42275a6f0f3ebdc0c4cd9324804

commit_message:
Make ceph::repo ensurable + add support for emperor

The ensure argument is added to ceph::repo and used in integration tests
to make sure the repository is removed the repository before installing
it. The integration tests do not re-create a virtual machine for each
test and the leftovers of the previous test must be cleaned.

The emperor Ceph release is now supported to be the default.

Closes-Bug: #1255940

Change-Id: Ib6da26b95be9f549d55bd88f867b43d6aa536f10
Signed-off-by: Loic Dachary <loic@dachary.org>

subject: use 'os_type' in ephemeral filename only if mkfs defined
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-18 15:07:38.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py', 'nova/tests/test_libvirt.py', 'nova/virt/disk/api.py'], 'message': "use 'os_type' in ephemeral filename only if mkfs defined

Currently for undefined os-types it will use the default mkfs
command, but use the meta 'os_type' in the name of the
ephemeral file (e.g. ephemeral_20_abcdef). Which can result
in a lot of files (DoS?)
This change will only use 'os_type' in the ephemeral filename
if there is a specific mkfs command defined, otherwise it will
use 'default' (e.g. ephemeral_20_default)

Modifed the tests to test for:
  os_type=''
  os_type=None
  os_type='test' - with no mkfs command specified
  os_type='test' - with a mkfs command specified

Closes-Bug: 1253980

Backport of Original Change-Id: Ie4c10f99ce690c5e4ef181624bd688c38923855c
to stable/grizzly

Change-Id: Ia040910e90861a2987eff345ad1c01863655b124
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
use 'os_type' in ephemeral filename only if mkfs defined

Currently for undefined os-types it will use the default mkfs
command, but use the meta 'os_type' in the name of the
ephemeral file (e.g. ephemeral_20_abcdef). Which can result
in a lot of files (DoS?)
This change will only use 'os_type' in the ephemeral filename
if there is a specific mkfs command defined, otherwise it will
use 'default' (e.g. ephemeral_20_default)

Modifed the tests to test for:
  os_type=''
  os_type=None
  os_type='test' - with no mkfs command specified
  os_type='test' - with a mkfs command specified

Closes-Bug: 1253980

Backport of Original Change-Id: Ie4c10f99ce690c5e4ef181624bd688c38923855c
to stable/grizzly

Change-Id: Ia040910e90861a2987eff345ad1c01863655b124

commit_message:
use 'os_type' in ephemeral filename only if mkfs defined

Currently for undefined os-types it will use the default mkfs
command, but use the meta 'os_type' in the name of the
ephemeral file (e.g. ephemeral_20_abcdef). Which can result
in a lot of files (DoS?)
This change will only use 'os_type' in the ephemeral filename
if there is a specific mkfs command defined, otherwise it will
use 'default' (e.g. ephemeral_20_default)

Modifed the tests to test for:
  os_type=''
  os_type=None
  os_type='test' - with no mkfs command specified
  os_type='test' - with a mkfs command specified

Closes-Bug: 1253980

Backport of Original Change-Id: Ie4c10f99ce690c5e4ef181624bd688c38923855c
to stable/havana

Change-Id: Ifa2b94e79dabd586d7e904da247d099360229313

commit_message:
Fixed autodoc can't import/find class error

The right module name should be `novaclient.v1_1.servers' instead of
`novaclient'. Similar fix on `images', `flavors' and `exceptions'.

Removed `ipgroups' and `backup_schedules' since they do not exist any
more.

Closes-Bug: #1056478

Change-Id: Id35f9c275fb36f3651a0bb2b0eb03c43f0aaeec1

in the workspace, don't put it in DEST (/opt/stack/...), that way
it doesn't interfere with anything that happens with /opt later.

the re-exec (into the just-updated copy).

commit_message:
Don't fix disks before rexecing

Do _even less_ before the rexec: the only action done is to
update $WORKSPACE/devstack-gate to the Zuul ref before doing
the re-exec (into the just-updated copy).

Change-Id: I74cb58ba35c4eeee6786a30ac35263758856f6f9

subject: Use the utils code in the 212 migration script
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-12-18 19:27:33.000000000', 'files': ['nova/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/212_fix_migrations_index.py'], 'message': "Use the utils code in the 212 migration script

The 212 migration has essentially copy/paste versions of the
add/drop/change indexes code that's in nova.db.sqlalchemy.utils but is
actually a bit out of date, in that it doesn't have commit aadc7b8 to
check the existence of an index before dropping it.

This patch removes the older code in the 212 script so it re-uses the
utility method. This will eventually be needed by bp db2-database to
avoid adding the 'ibm_db_sa' engine in multiple locations for the same
code.

Related to blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: I929b609ca038346f6e9cc931fcc22d99640b78c1
", 'number': 1}]
commit_message:
Use the utils code in the 212 migration script

The 212 migration has essentially copy/paste versions of the
add/drop/change indexes code that's in nova.db.sqlalchemy.utils but is
actually a bit out of date, in that it doesn't have commit aadc7b8 to
check the existence of an index before dropping it.

This patch removes the older code in the 212 script so it re-uses the
utility method. This will eventually be needed by bp db2-database to
avoid adding the 'ibm_db_sa' engine in multiple locations for the same
code.

Related to blueprint db2-database

Change-Id: I929b609ca038346f6e9cc931fcc22d99640b78c1

commit_message:
Make sure API is up before running tests

The functional tests were failing most of the time in the devstack-gate
job because the tests would run before solum-api was up and running.
This check makes sure the API is responding before the tests run.

Change-Id: I03f56349654cf08bd71fcc4b3af8008c83cd55eb
